chunks.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation

That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the share of each in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been adequately demonstrated by the ancients, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. And we ourselves have also stated what is reasonable concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step following that work, I shall proceed in this present writing to discover all the differences of mixtures [temperaments], both how many they are and of what kind, dividing them by species and genera, beginning from an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they speak of an animal, or a plant, as hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can be extremely hot, like fire, nor extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither extremely cold nor extremely dry. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture, we calling "moist" that in which there is a greater share of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is a greater share of dryness; and similarly "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.openai_translation:
That, then, the bodies of animals are compounded from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, and that in the mixture [krâsis] the share of all is not equal, has been adequately demonstrated by men of old, the best among philosophers and physicians; and I too have set forth the likely considerations on these matters in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, as a sequel to that, I will in this treatise go through all the differences of the mixtures—how many they are and of what sort—dividing them into species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever people say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, they maintain that one should understand these in the strict sense, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when it is a question of an animal, or a plant, or of calling something hot or cold or dry or moist, it is not so. For no living thing can exist that is hot in the extreme like fire, nor moist in the extreme like water; and likewise it cannot be to the utmost degree cold or dry. Rather, the designations are derived from what predominates in the mixture: we call that “moist” in which the portion of moisture is greater, and “dry” that in which [the portion] of dryness [is greater]; and in the same way, “hot” where the hot prevails over the cold, and “cold” where the cold prevails over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.gemini_translation:
That the bodies of animals, then, are compounded from the hot and the cold, the dry and the wet, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture [krasis], has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients—by the best among philosophers and physicians. And we ourselves have also discussed these matters fittingly in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates.

But now, as the next task in order, I shall in this present treatise proceed to investigate all the differences among the temperaments [kraseis]—how many and of what sort they are—dividing them according to species and genera, and beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, they mean we should understand this as referring to things that are so in an absolute sense, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when they call an animal or a plant hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can exist that is absolutely hot, like fire, or absolutely wet, like water; and likewise, none can be cold or dry to the utmost degree. Rather, the designations arise from the quality that predominates in the mixture, so that we call a thing wet in which there is a greater share of wetness, and dry in which there is a greater share of dryness; and likewise hot, in which the hot predominates over the cold, and cold, in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the use of these terms.

chunks.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί. ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει.
chunks.claude_translation: Now it would be time to speak also about the temperaments themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot temperament, another that is moist and cold, and a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain temperament that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; however, neither one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry. For it is not possible either for moisture to accompany predominant heat, or for dryness to accompany coldness. For moisture is consumed by prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry, while in those bodies in which heat is weak, it remains undigested and unprocessed, so that it is necessary that when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when coldness prevails, moisture follows. These people, then, have convinced themselves on these grounds that there are altogether two varieties of temperaments. But those who believe there are four oppose them in two ways: some by immediately not conceding the first premise, that it is necessary for moisture to be dried up by prevailing heat; while others concede this point but dispute it in another way. Now the first group say that the function of heat is to heat, just as that of cold is to cool, and again that of dryness is to dry, just as that of moisture is to moisten. And because of this, those bodies that are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, insofar as they are hot, heat, and insofar as they are dry, dry.
chunks.gemini_translation:
It would now be the time to speak of the temperaments [kraseis] themselves. The most widespread opinion, then, of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a wet and hot temperament, another that is wet and cold, a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is at once dry and hot.

Some of them, however, assert that a temperament that is at once wet and cold exists, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, however, one that is at once wet and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For they say it is not possible for wetness to coincide with a prevailing hotness, nor for dryness with coldness. For moisture is consumed by the dominant heat, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry, while in those bodies in which the heat is weak, it remains undigested and unelaborated, so that it is necessary, when hotness prevails, for dryness to follow, and when coldness has the upper hand, for wetness to ensue. These thinkers, then, have persuaded themselves on these grounds that the varieties of temperaments are two in all.

But those who believe there are four argue against them in two ways: some, by not conceding the first premise [axioma] from the outset—namely, that moisture is necessarily dried out by the dominant heat; while others concede this point, but dispute it on other grounds. The first group, then, asserts that the function [ergon] of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and, in turn, that of the dry is to dry, just as that of the wet is to moisten. And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature at once hot and dry, such as fire, they heat insofar as they are hot, and they dry insofar as they are dry.
chunks.openai_translation: It would now be time to speak also about their mixtures [kraseis/temperaments]. The most prevalent opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is a hot-and-moist mixture, another the moist-and-cold, and, in addition to these, a third, the dry-and-cold, and another, the dry-and-hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain mixture that is at once moist and cold, and another that is at once hot and dry; yet not one that is at once moist and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible for moisture to go together with heat when the latter predominates, nor for dryness with cold. For when heat is dominant it expends the moisture, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry; whereas it remains uncocted and unworked [i.e., not processed by “coction”] in those bodies in which the hot element is diseased, so that it is necessary that, when heat prevails, dryness follows, and when cold predominates, moisture accompanies. These people, then, have in this way convinced themselves that all the differences of mixtures are two in number. Those who think there are four oppose them in two ways: some do not concede the initial axiom, namely that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by prevailing heat; others concede this, but dispute in another way. The first say that the work of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and in turn that of the dry is to dry, just as that of the moist is to moisten. And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, heat insofar as they are hot, and dry insofar as they are dry.

chunks.content: ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος. ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς.
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.2:

Things that are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally disposed always to moisten and to heat, each quality having in this case too a single inseparable function. Therefore, they do not concede that if something heats, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, so too it is dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they remind us of those who have spent excessive time in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become parched, having their whole body both dry and withered, and suffering from unbearable thirst.
chunks.openai_translation: Whatever things are moist and hot—like hot water—are by nature always inclined both to moisten and to heat, each of the two qualities here having its own single, inseparable effect. Accordingly, it is not to be conceded that, if something is heating, it at once also dries; rather, if moisture is conjoined with the heat, it both heats and moistens at the same time, as do baths of fresh water [i.e., non-saline]. But if, in addition to being hot, it were also dry—like fire—it would not only heat but immediately dry as well, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they further recall those who have spent time in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become parched, their whole body being both dry and rough, and their thirst intolerable.
chunks.gemini_translation: But such things as are both wet and hot, like hot water, are by nature always moistening and heating, with the work of each quality [ποιότητος] in this case too being one and inseparable. Therefore, they do not grant that if something is heating, it immediately also dries; but rather, if wetness is present with the heat, the thing heats and at the same time moistens, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, it should also be dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this effect not from its heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And in this context they bring to mind those who have spent too much time in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become withered, having their whole body both dry and parched, and being unbearably thirsty.

chunks.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει. Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν.
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.3:

For they say that a cure is ready and very easy for them, not only if they should drink, but also if they should bathe in warm and sweet waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be accompanied by coldness or by heat, is able to perform its own function—namely, to moisten things that come near it. And according to the same reasoning, they say that dryness always dries. At any rate, the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries a newly watered threshing floor." And in the same manner both the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.
chunks.openai_translation: For they say that for them there is a cure ready to hand and easiest—not only if they were to drink, but even if they were to bathe in warm and “sweet” waters [i.e., fresh, non-saline]—since moisture [hygrotēs], whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to do what is proper to it; for it moistens what is near. And by the same reasoning they say that dryness [xērotēs] always dries. Indeed Boreas, being a dry and cold wind, dries everything and cools. And this is what is meant by the Homeric line: “As when the autumnal Boreas quickly dries a newly watered threshing-floor.” Likewise, the juice of the poppy [opium; the latex of the poppy] and countless other drugs at once dry and cool.
chunks.gemini_translation: For they say that a cure is ready and very easy for them, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in hot and fresh waters, since wetness is able to perform its own function—for it moistens whatever is near—whether it be combined with coldness or with heat. And according to the same principle, they say that dryness always dries. The north wind, for instance, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools all things. And this, they say, is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind swiftly dries a newly watered threshing-floor." And in the same way, the juice [Greek: *opos*] of the poppy and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.

chunks.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος.
chunks.claude_translation: Therefore it is not necessary that if something is cold, it should immediately also be moist, nor that if something is hot, it should immediately also be dry. Consequently, neither is it necessary that a hot mixture [*krasis*, blend or temperament] should also be dry, but it is possible sometimes for the hot to predominate over the cold in the mixture of the living creature, and the moist over the dry. For indeed both generation and alteration and change occur from contraries into contraries. For who, having said that the white has been altered and changed—for it has become hot—would not be laughable? For the argument seeks not the opposition according to cold and hot, but the change according to color. For the white changes into the black, just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold also into the hot. And so too the moist into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist. For if someone should claim that the body has been altered by the fact that what was formerly moist is now white, or by the fact that what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to speak reasonably. For what changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect move toward its opposite. "This person has become or is becoming musical," we say, clearly from being non-musical, and literate from being non-literate, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or that something comes to be from some other heterogeneous quality is absurd. For it is possible that one who was formerly literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having cast off literacy. And yet if he has acquired something in addition while the former quality remains, it is surely clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. So he has not become musical from being literate—for indeed he is still literate even now—but musical from being non-musical. For it is no longer possible for him to remain non-musical, having already become musical. Since, then, all changes occur by contraries and from contraries into contraries, clearly also the moist, if it ever changes, insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and what dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not say that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples given a little earlier. Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers.
chunks.gemini_translation:
Thus, it is not necessary, either that if something is cold, it is immediately also moist, or that if something is hot, it is immediately also dry. Therefore, a hot temperament [κρᾶσις] is not necessarily also a dry one, but it is possible for the hot to predominate over the cold in the temperament of a living being, while the moist predominates over the dry. For indeed, generation, alteration [ἀλλοίωσις, qualitative change], and change [μεταβολή, general change] all occur from opposites into their opposites. For who, then, would not be ridiculous for saying that "the white thing was altered and changed, for it became hot"? For the argument requires not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change in respect to color. For white changes into black, just as black also changes into white, and hot, in turn, into cold, just as cold also changes into hot. And so too does the moist change into the dry, and the dry, in turn, into the moist. For if someone were to claim that a body has been altered because what was formerly moist is now white, or because what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be of sound mind. But if he were to say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or that it has become cold from being hot, or hot from being cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to be speaking plausibly. For that which changes must, in the respect in which it changes, pass over to its opposite.

For instance, we say that this man became, or is becoming, a musician from being non-musical, obviously; and a grammarian from being non-grammatical, and a rhetorician from being non-rhetorical. But to say that someone becomes a grammarian from being a musician, or a musician from being a grammarian, or that anything comes to be from something else of a different kind [ἑτερογενῶν], is absurd. For it is possible for one who was formerly a grammarian to have now become a musician, by acquiring the art of music in addition to the art of grammar, not by casting off the art of grammar. And surely, if he acquired something new while the former quality remained, it is clear to everyone that he was not altered with respect to that which remained. Thus, he did not become a musician *from* being a grammarian—for indeed he is still a grammarian now—but rather a musician *from* being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become a musician.

Therefore, since all changes are brought about by opposites and proceed from opposites to opposites, it is clear that the moist, if it ever changes *qua* moist, will itself be dried, and that which dries it will be called dry. Let them not, therefore, say—as they do—that it is impossible for a temperament to be at once hot and moist. For it is impossible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once moist and dry, for it is not possible for opposite qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a short while ago have shown.

Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers.
chunks.openai_translation:
Accordingly, it is not necessary that, if something is cold, it should at once also be moist, nor that, if something is hot, it should at once also be dry. Hence a hot blend [krasis: mixture/temperament] is not of necessity also dry; rather, it can happen at times that, in the mixture of a living creature, the hot prevails over the cold, while the moist prevails over the dry. For indeed both coming-to-be, alteration, and change [genesis, alloiōsis, metabolē] occur from contraries into contraries. For who would not be laughable if he said, “The white thing has been altered and has changed—for it became hot”? For the discussion is looking not for the opposition according to cold and hot, but for the change according to color; for white changes into black, just as black into white, and again the hot into the cold, just as the cold into the hot. And so too the moist into the dry, and in turn the dry into the moist. For if someone claims that the body has been altered in that, being formerly moist, it is now white, or in that, being formerly dry, it now appears black, he would seem not to be in his right mind. But if he were to say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously existed as black is now white, or that from being hot it has become cold, or from being cold hot, such a person would seem sensible and to be speaking plausibly. For that which changes must, in the very respect in which it changes, pass over toward the opposite.

Accordingly, we say “This person became, or becomes, musical from being unmusical, plainly, and literate from being illiterate, and a rhetorician from not being a rhetorician” [grammatikos: literate, skilled in letters]; but it is absurd to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or from something else among things of a different kind [heterogeneous]. For it is admissible that someone who was previously literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having discarded literacy. And indeed, if he has acquired something while the former state remains, it is clear to everyone, I suppose, that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. Therefore he did not become musical from being literate; for even now he is still literate. Rather, he became musical from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become musical. Since, at any rate, all changes are brought about both by contraries and from contraries into contraries, it is evident that the moist too, if it ever changes, in so far as it is moist, will itself be dried, and what dries it will be said to be dry.

Therefore, let no one, as they say, assert that it is impossible for a blend to come to be both hot and moist at once. For it is not possible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, nor both moist and dry; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to co-exist in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has shown and the examples mentioned a little earlier. Such, then, is the account of the predecessors.

chunks.content: ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου. ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι.
chunks.claude_translation: But the proponent of the second view says there is nothing absurd, given that the hot is the most active of the four [qualities], so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, in there being a moist and hot mixture whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time right at the first generation of the animal. But the argument of those people does not demonstrate that it could never happen that in one and the same body the moist exceeds the dry while the hot exceeds the cold, but rather that such a state could not remain so forever. For the moisture, being constantly evaporated by the heat, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. And then again, this very thing, the hot and dry, as time advances, will become dry and cold. For whenever the heat has consumed all its moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having an abundant supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore they consider it not at all remarkable both that at the beginning, right at the first generation of the animal, either the moist exceeds the dry or the hot exceeds the cold, coming together at the same time. And it is also possible that as time progresses, the mixture that was previously hot and moist becomes in turn hot and dry, just as again in turn the dry and hot mixture, when the heat is extinguished, becomes cold and dry.
chunks.gemini_translation: The proponent of the second view, however, says that there is nothing strange—on the assumption that the hot is the most active of the four qualities, such that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the wet—in there being a wet and hot temperament [κρᾶσις], whenever a great amount of both wetness and hotness comes together at the same time, right at the first generation of the living being. But the argument of those others shows not that it could never happen in one and the same body that the wet is more than the dry and the hot more than the cold, but that such a state could not remain forever. For the wet, being always dried out by the hot, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and wet, but would be hot and dry. Then this very state, the hot and dry, will in turn, as time advances, become dry and cold. For whenever the hot has consumed all of the body's moisture [ἰκμάς], from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer having an abundance of the nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore, they think it is not at all surprising for either a preponderance of the wet over the dry, or of the hot over the cold, to come together in the same place at the very beginning, right at the first generation of the living being. And it is possible, as time goes on, for the temperament that was for a time hot and wet to become in turn hot and dry; just as, in turn, the dry and hot temperament, with the hot being extinguished, can be rendered cold and dry.
chunks.openai_translation:
But the advocate of the second view says there is nothing absurd in assuming that the hot is the most active of the four [primary qualities], in that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist; thus there is a moist-and-hot krasis [mixture] whenever a large amount of both moisture and heat come together into one at the same time, right at the animal’s first coming-to-be.

Their argument does not show that it could never occur in one and the same body that the moist is more than the dry and the hot more than the cold, but rather that such a state would not endure forever; for the moist, being continually dried out by the hot, will in time render the body dry. And thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry; and this condition itself again, the hot-and-dry, with a further advance of time will become dry and cold. For whenever the hot has consumed all its ikmas [succulence] from it [i.e., from the body], from that point, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer well supplied with the nourishment from which it was kindled.

Accordingly, they think it nothing surprising if at the outset—straightaway at the animal’s first generation—either the moist more than the dry, or the hot more than the cold, come together in one and the same subject. And it is also possible, as time goes on, for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become hot and dry again, just as, again in turn, the dry-and-hot, when the hot is being quenched, comes to be cold and dry.

chunks.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν.
chunks.claude_translation: "That it is possible, then, for one mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another mixture different from this one to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four varieties of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following arguments."
chunks.openai_translation: Accordingly, that it is indeed possible for something to be both hot and moist at the same time, and that another mixture [krasis: mixture/constitution] different from this one is cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four varieties of mixtures, they try to show from the following.
chunks.gemini_translation: From the preceding points, then, they demonstrate that it is possible for one temperament [krasis] to be at once hot and moist, and for another to be cold and dry. But from the following points, they attempt to teach that it is impossible for more than four varieties of temperaments to exist.

chunks.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας. ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν.
chunks.claude_translation: For they say that there being four underlying qualities, which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist, and because of this all the combinations amount to four. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings result, but two of these turn out to be impossible. For a body can become neither moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. It remains, therefore, that there are four combinations of mixtures [or temperaments]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. These, then, are the things that the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.
chunks.openai_translation: For, they say, since there are four underlying qualities [poiotētes]—heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—which have the capacity to act upon and be acted upon by one another, two oppositions arise: the one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the wet; and for this reason the whole set of pairings [syzygies] amounts to four. For the couplings [syzeugseis] of the four, as they are interwoven with one another, come to six; but two of these are impossible. For a body cannot be at the same time both wet and dry, nor at the same time both cold and hot. Accordingly, it remains that there are four pairings of mixtures [kraseis]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and by cold. Such, then, are the statements of the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us.
chunks.gemini_translation: For, they say, with four underlying qualities—heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—which possess the capacity to act upon and be affected by one another, two oppositions arise: the one, in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other, in which the dry is opposed to the wet; and for this reason four total combinations [syzygies] are produced. For while six pairings result from the four being interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible. For a body cannot be at once wet and dry, nor at once cold and hot. So it remains that there are four combinations of mixtures [kraseis], two wet and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. These, then, are the things that the most distinguished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.

chunks.content: ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
chunks.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

But as for the things which I believe they have omitted, it is now time to speak.
chunks.openai_translation: But as for the things I think they have omitted, now is the time to speak.
chunks.gemini_translation: But what I believe they have omitted, it is now the opportune moment to state.
